This report was prepared by a team consisting of R. Stroem (team leader),  T. Takano,  
I. Caetani, A. Mohammed, and A. Aleem.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) country programming missions in 2004, the 
Government of Pakistan reconfirmed its request for assistance to prepare a power transmission 
system project to enhance overall power system efficiency. A project preparatory technical 
assistance (PPTA) for the Power Transmission Enhancement Project1 is included in ADB’s 
country strategy and program update2 (CSPU), 2005–2006 and an ensuing loan project is 
included in the lending program for 2006. An ADB fact-finding mission visited Pakistan from 
31 May to 9 June 2005, and reached an understanding with the Government on the objective, 
scope, cost, financing, implementation arrangements, and the consultants’ outline terms of 
reference for the PPTA. The PPTA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
2.  The National Transmission and Despatch Company (NTDC) is responsible for national 
power transmission, the dispatch center, and it is the single electricity buyer and seller. NTDC 
was established through a restructuring and unbundling of the power wing of the Water and 
Power Development Authority (WAPDA).  NTDC is responsible for linking the power generation 
facilities with load centers throughout the country, and is composed of lines and grid stations of 
500 kilovolt (kV) and 220 kV capacities. NTDC is responsible for the construction, operation, 
and maintenance of transmission facilities throughout Pakistan. It also constructs 132 and 66 kV 
grid stations and transmission lines for the distribution companies.  At the end of June 2004, 
NTDC operated and maintained nine 500 kV and 24 220 kV grid stations and 10,167 km of 
transmission lines. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Pakistan’s  Medium  Term  Development  Framework  2005–20103  (MTDF)  sets  out  a 
challenging infrastructure investment program, in order to achieve a consistent 8% annual 
growth in gross domestic product (GDP). The overarching philosophy of the Government is 
poverty reduction through economic development.  An increase in the supply of infrastructure 
services creates economic opportunities in both urban and rural areas. The power sector is a  
fundamental infrastructure sector and the transmission system needs to be strengthened and 
expanded to support the Government’s economic growth target and its poverty reduction efforts.  
 
4.  Electricity demand in Pakistan is forecast to grow by 8.3% a year during the period 
2005–2015. To cope with this growth in demand, it is estimated that Pakistan would require 
about 2,000 additional megawatts (MWs) annually, which would need to be evacuated through 
the transmission system. Substantial investments are required to strengthen the transmission 
system to (i) evacuate the power generated by additional power plants, and (ii) supply electricity 
to meet the growing demand.  NTDC currently has a transmission development program for the 
period 2005–2012 and several schemes included in the program have been approved by the 
Government.  
 
5.  Pakistan’s transmission system faces three major challenges: (i) the heavy power flow 
through the 500 kV system, (ii) a shortage of supply capacity for the 220 kV system, and 
(iii) high transmission losses.  As most of the major hydropower plants are located in the 
northern part of the country, there is heavy power flow from north to south during summer when 
hydropower  plant  generation  is  high,  and  heavy  flow  from  south  to  north  in  winter  when

hydropower generation is low. Although the capacity of the 500 kV system is expected to 
increase by 2006 after the commissioning of two 500 kV transmission lines, this issue may recur 
in the near future because of the uneven distribution of additional power plants. There are  
system  constraints  in  the  220kV  system,  mainly  shortages  of  supply  at  the  220/132  kV 
substations  and  related  220kV  transmission  line  systems.  These  supply  shortages  cause 
(i) load  shedding,  (ii)  low  voltage  profiles,  and  (iii)  high  transmission  system  losses.  The 
Government has approved some enhancement schemes to address these, but forecasted high 
growth in electricity demand will require further strengthening of the 220 kV system.  
 
6.  Transmission and distribution losses in Pakistan amounted to 24.3% in FY2003–2004.  
These substantial losses are mainly caused by the excess load on transmission lines and 
transformers. Because of aging and overloading, the transmission system is unstable and 
unreliable, and it is of crucial importance that it is improved in these respects. Consumers 
require a reliable supply of power, as do the production and service sectors.  
 
7.  Two  issues  affecting  the  financial  and  economic  sustainability  of  the  power  sector 
require detailed attention. First, the operational and financial autonomy of NTDC needs further 
refinement. NTDC, as part of the overall power sector, is going through a transformation from a 
single  integrated  utility  to  an  unbundled  sector  operating  as  a  single  buyer.  Although  the 
transformation is ongoing, the transfer of tasks and duties needs to be speeded up, which will 
result  in  a  shorter  transition  period  and  greater  system  efficiency.  Before  the  proposed 
transmission enhancement project is considered by ADB, it is expected that NTDC’s degree of 
autonomy will have increased from its current level.  
 
8.  Second, the financial viability of NTDC and the single buyer model affect the financial 
and economic sustainability of the power sector. According to its license, NTDC has three main 
functions; (i) the transmission function, (ii) the load dispatch function, and (iii) the single buyer 
and single seller functions. The first two are generally accepted and understood and for the third 
the Government is developing a  central power purchase agency (CPPA). The  consultants 
engaged under the technical assistance for capacity building of NTDC4 are assisting in this. The 
CPPA functions need to be clearly defined before any decision on, or implementation of, the 
proposed transmission enhancement project. The overall tariff to be charged by the distribution 
companies to the consumers will be linked to the financial viability of NTDC. This issue is 
currently being reviewed by the Government with a view to limiting the deficit of the power 
sector and its impact on the national budget.  A decision is expected soon and it is envisioned 
that this issue will be resolved during the PPTA period.  
 
9.  Compared with best international practices, NTDC currently pays limited attention to 
safeguard issues. Stricter compliance with internationally acceptable safeguard policies and 
procedures will be required if NTDC is to obtain international funding for transmission projects. 
Before any financial assistance is provided, due diligence should be carried out to assess the 
impacts  of  the  transmission  projects  and  to  ensure  that  negative  impacts  are  properly 
addressed as per ADB’s safeguard policies and procedures. ADB safeguard policies cover the 
environment,  involuntary  resettlement,  and  indigenous  peoples5  (IPs).  At  present,  NTDC 
addresses involuntary resettlement and IPs on a case-by-case basis. Because of its lack of 
internal resources and specialized personnel, assessments of environmental and social impacts

are outsourced to consulting firms, which undertake the due diligence and report to NTDC, after 
conducting full consultations with all the stakeholders involved. 
 
10.  In terms of environmental assessment, NTDC carries out a pre-assessment to define a 
provisional routing. Consultants then prepare a more detailed assessment of the environmental 
impacts. The Pakistan Environmental Protection Act of 1997 defines the legal procedure to be 
undertaken,  in  terms  of  environmental  impact  assessment,  before  the  submission  and 
implementation of any project. The act provides guidance and principles on environmental 
impact assessment, which are supported by guidelines issued by the Pakistan Environmental 
Protection Agency and provincial environmental protection agencies. 
 
11.  With regard to land acquisition, Pakistan currently relies on the Land Acquisition Act of 
1894, and the Telegraph Act (or Electricity Act) of 1910. A new national law on Land Acquisition 
and Resettlement was drafted in 2002 in cooperation with ADB and the World Bank. This law is 
yet to be approved. The acts currently used by the Government allow for provisions to be 
adopted within each project that meet ADB safeguards requirements. NTDC has implemented 
projects  with  international  financial  institutions  in  the  past,  and  it  fully  accepts  that  the 
subsequent  projects  will  have  to  develop  resettlement  plans  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
standards. Concerns that will need to be addressed during the implementation of the PPTA are 
related to (i) untitled land users, (ii) agricultural labor presently employed (formally or not) in the 
affected areas, (iii) equitable household compensation, and (iv) marginalized minorities.  
 
12.  IPs, as defined by ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998), are the responsibility of 
the Ministry of Religious Affairs. Because there is no clear definition of mainstream population or 
minorities  in  Pakistan,  mapping  of  IPs  who  are  relevant  to  NTDC’s  operations  may  be 
necessary. Discrimination against IPs must be avoided, particularly when compensation and job 
opportunities are being awarded. The same applies to women and other vulnerable groups. 
   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The  purpose  of  the  PPTA  is  to  support  the  Government’s  strategy  of  increasing 
electricity  supply  to  its  urban  and  rural  population.  It  will  do  this  by  preparing  a  power 
transmission enhancement project to ensure the transmission system delivers a sufficient and 
stable power supply. The project will improve system stability and reliability, and reduce losses 
through (i) the construction of 500 kV and 220 kV transmission lines, (ii) the construction of 500 
kV  and  220  kV  substations,  (iii)  an  extension  of  500  kV  and  220  kV  substations,  and 
(iv) preparation of a master plan on a nationwide transmission system. A similar intervention for 
the distribution system has been included in the 2007 ADB lending program. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
14.  Key activities to be undertaken under the PPTA cover four major areas: (i) technical 
project design; (ii) economic and financial evaluations; (iii) compliance with national and ADB 
safeguard policies; and (iv) links among economic growth, poverty, and the power sector. In 
finalizing the technical project design, a detailed review of load forecasts will be undertaken with 
a view to ensuring least-cost technical design and economic viability of the proposed investment 
project. Feasibility studies will be reviewed, and a procurement plan prepared.

4   
15.  In addition to financial analysis of the Project, the financial management capabilities and 
the financial performance of NTDC will be assessed. Financial management is important as 
NTDC was recently unbundled from WAPDA, and separate financial management systems are 
needed for its transmission operations and its single buyer function. The tariff structure will be 
reviewed  to  determine  whether  the  actual  cost  of  supply  is  being  recovered  and/or  being 
subsidized  through  a  transparent  mechanism.  Interaction  with  the  National  Electric  Power 
Regulatory Authority will ensure understanding and  knowledge about the tariff application and 
determination issues. Economic subsidies in the current tariff structure and the extent of cross-
subsidization between major consumer groups and regions will be analyzed. Existing estimates 
of the costs of unserved energy due to the unreliability of the system will be updated, and 
several scenarios for the load growth forecast will be developed, paying particular importance to 
potential impacts of external shocks on the economy.   
 
16.  Detailed field surveys will be undertaken to ensure compliance with ADB’s safeguard 
policies for the environment, involuntary resettlement, and IPs. The surveys will be carried out 
along the planned alignment of the transmission lines, the sites of the new grid stations, and the 
access roads to identify any environmental impacts, and to prepare a full inventory of all land, 
businesses, shops, and households that will be permanently or temporarily affected by the 
project. The Project will be designed, transmission lines aligned and routed, and substations 
located in order to minimize adverse environmental and social impact. Mitigation measures and 
implementation arrangements will also be assessed. An initial environmental examination and a 
summary initial environmental examination will be prepared. A full resettlement plan will be 
prepared, since both temporary and permanent impacts on affected persons are expected to be 
significant.6 The resettlement plan will include design of public information, disclosure and 
grievance procedures, and costing of compensation. The project’s impacts are not expected to 
cause any specific cultural or social impacts on any socioeconomic group, including indigenous 
people, or to exclude any from benefiting from the proposed investment project. Particular 
attention will be devoted to minorities, women, and other vulnerable groups. An indigenous 
peoples development plan (IPDP) may be required.  
 
17.  The rationale for the proposed 500 kV and 220 kV transmission lines and the new 
500 kV and 220 kV substations is closely related to specific generation expansion projects. 
Thus, any delay in the construction of those plants, or change to the location of the plants, might 
make the proposed investments in the transmission line and substation unjustifiable. This is a 
potential risk for the project’s economic and financial viability. Since the MTDF sets out the 
power sector investment needs over a specified period of time, a sector project approach for the 
ensuing loan would introduce sufficient flexibility in case these generation plants are delayed. 
Under the PPTA, suitable selection criteria for specific area coverage and components will be 
developed and decided upon by the Government, NTDC, and ADB. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the PPTA is estimated at $675,000 equivalent, of which the foreign 
exchange cost is $307,000 and the local currency cost is $368,000 equivalent. The Government 
has asked ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent, comprising the entire foreign exchange cost 
and a portion of the local currency cost amounting to $193,000 equivalent. The PPTA will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The

5
Government and NTDC will finance the remaining $175,000 equivalent of local currency costs 
through in-kind contributions by NTDC, including office accommodation and facilities, local 
communication, counterpart staff, data, and other information needed for the PPTA. Detailed 
cost estimates are provided in Appendix 2. The Government has been advised that ADB’s 
approval of the PPTA does not commit ADB to financing any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  MOWP will be the Executing Agency, and NTDC the Implementing Agency for the 
proposed PPTA. NTDC has adequate experience with implementing similar externally funded 
projects from its earlier role as an integrated part of WAPDA. In addition, MOWP will provide 
assistance to the PPTA consultants in liaising with other Government ministries and agencies 
and with provincial authorities, and in obtaining data and documentation from these ministries, 
agencies, and provincial authorities. NTDC, with assistance from MOWP, will liaise with the 
provinces  affected  by  the  proposed  investment  project  to  ensure  coordination  and 
understanding of the proposed project.  
 
20.  The PPTA will require about 11 person-months of international and 29 person-months of 
domestic  consulting  services,  which  are  expected  to  begin  on  1  November  2005  and  be 
completed by 30 April 2006. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are provided in 
Appendix 3. Tripartite meetings, involving NTDC, MOWP, and ADB, will be held after the 
submission of the inception, interim, and draft final reports. The consultants will prepare status 
reports for their specific scope of works, highlighting any issues that could become critical for 
the timely completion of the PPTA. The consultants will arrange for workshops and on-the-job 
training for NTDC and MOWP staff and for provincial and local governments. The international 
consultants will have expertise in project and energy economics and macroeconomic modeling, 
financial analysis and financial management, power system and transmission system planning, 
power  system  analysis,  transmission  line  and  substation  design,  environmental  impact 
assessment, resettlement, and other social issues. A consulting firm or consortium of firms will 
be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. Recruitment of 
consultants will be according to quality- and cost-based selection procedures, and simplified 
technical proposals will be requested. Equipment to be financed under the TA will be procured 
in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
   
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Pakistan for preparing the Power Transmission Enhancement Project, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The consultants’ scope of work will cover four major areas: (i) compliance with the Asian 
Development Bank’s (ADB) safeguard policies; (ii) economic and financial evaluations; (iii) links 
between economic growth, poverty, and the power sector; and (iv) technical project design. The 
consultants’ terms of reference will include, but not necessarily be limited, to the following. 
 
A.  Engineering Aspects (international, 4 person-months; domestic, 10 person-months) 
2.  The consultants’ outline terms of reference will include, but will not necessarily be limited 
to, the following tasks: 
 
(i)  review NTDC’s power systems and their midterm investment plans, and identify 
priority subprojects for ADB funding with a focus on transmission system (500 kV 
and  220  kV)  and  substations  (in  identifying  priority  subprojects,  review  the 
justification of the subprojects, including technical specifications);  
(ii)  review NTDC’s transmission system study and carry out an additional study to 
determine whether the proposed subprojects provide the least cost solution for 
meeting the required transmission capability; 
(iii)  review and update project cost estimates, separating foreign exchange and local 
currency,  prepare  a  list  of  materials,  equipment,  and  works  necessary  to 
implement the subprojects,  and, based on the result of the route survey, prepare 
a transmission line profile and tower spottings; 
(iv)  prepare  project  implementation  and  procurement  arrangements  including 
contract packaging in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on Procurement, and a 
project implementation schedule; 
(v)  prepare engineering designs and technical specification of transmission lines, 
including towers, conductors, insulators, ground wires, etc. in accordance with 
relevant  technical  standards,  prepare  engineering  designs  and  technical 
specification  of  substations  in  accordance  with  relevant  technical  standards, 
prepare bill of quantities for all materials required, based on the engineering 
design, and prepare detailed cost estimates for contract packages, specifying 
whether costs are in foreign exchange or local currency; and   
(vi)  prepare detailed project implementation schedules showing anticipated progress 
of works and expenditures for each contract package and taking into account 
seasonal  climatic  conditions,  prepare  engineering  drawings  required  for  the 
preparation  of  bidding  documents,  and  prepare  bidding  documents  for  the 
subprojects following ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement and Standard Bidding 
Documents.  
 
B.  Financial Analysis (international, 2 person-months; domestic, 5 person-months) 
3.  In  accordance  with  Guidelines  for  the  Financial  Governance  and  Management  of 
Investment Projects Financed by the Asian Development Bank1 (2001), the consultant will 
conduct financial analysis of the proposed Project and the Implementing Agency, the National 
Transmission and Despatch Company (NTDC). This will include preparation of relevant sections 
of the report and recommendation of the President of ADB. The consultant will:

C.  Economic  Evaluation  (international,  2  person-months;  domestic,  5  person-

(i)  evaluate the economic rationale for government involvement by comparing the

evaluating  capacity  in  economic  analysis  and  to  apply  economic  selection 
criteria, evaluate the overall analysis of NTDC’s capacity, and determine the 
proper  mode  for  ADB's  involvement,  including  whether  a  sector  loan  is 
appropriate. 
 
D.  Environmental Aspects (international, 1 person-months; domestic, 5 person-months) 
6.  In accordance with the relevant guidelines and policies for environmental assessment, 
the consultants will undertake the following tasks, including preparation of relevant sections of 
the report and recommendation of the President as outlined below: 
 
(i)  conduct  an  initial  environmental  examination  for  the  transmission  line  and 
substations, taking into account the likely impacts associated with their locations, 
designs, and construction activities, as well as the long-term impacts during 
operation, including identification of environmental issues from activities directly 
induced by the Project; 
(ii)  based  on  the  review  of  rapid  and  comprehensive  environmental  impact 
assessment reports prepared for the projects, provide MOWP and NTDC with 
specific and detailed recommendations for revisions and/or additional studies, if 
needed, to make the environmental assessments and EIA conform to ADB’s 
requirements  based  on  Operations  Manual  F1/BP  and  F1/OP  (2003), 
Environment Policy (2002) and Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003), 
and consider lessons learned from past and ongoing transmission financed by 
ADB and other international financial institutions; 
(iii)  assess whether the proposed transmission components are within the protected 
areas and, if they lie within such zones, determine the regulatory procedures and 
protection measures needed to obtain environmental and forestry clearance from 
the relevant national and provincial government agencies and further assess the 
adequacy of the EIA report and environmental management plan (EMP) with 
specific reference to riverine ecology and suggest additional measures, if the 
EMP is found to be inadequate; 
(iv)  ensure that necessary mitigation measures are in place, assess the adequacy of 
the  cost  estimates  for  the  proposed  environmental  management  plans,  and 
review the environmental management capability of management units of NTDC 
and recommend institutional strengthening measures;  
(v)  prepare a summary EIA for the transmission and the substations in accordance 
with ADB’s Operations Manual F1/BP and F1/OP (2003), Environment Policy 
(2002),  Environmental  Assessment  Guidelines  (2003),  and  any  applicable 
procedures  or  guidelines  for  environmental  assessment  required  by  the 
Government;  and  ensure  that  components  such  as  transmission  lines  and

Appendix 3 11
access roads specifically for the project must have environmental assessments 
even if they are not financed by ADB; 
(vi)  recommend  appropriate  environmental  mitigation  measures  for  identified 
significant impacts and monitoring plans to address these impacts; and assess 
the  environmental  benefits  of  the  proposed  activities  and  any  capacity-
strengthening  measures  that  may  be  needed  for  the  implementation  of 
environmental management and monitoring plans, and 
(vii)  if the IEE recommends a full EIA, conduct the EIA and prepare the report and its 
summary, including an environmental management plan to implement mitigation 
measures. 
 
E.  Involuntary Resettlement and Indigenous Peoples, (international, 2 person-months; 
domestic, 4 person-months) 
7.  The consultants will: 
 
(i)  review national laws and policies on land acquisition and involuntary resettlement 
to  verify  their  adequacy  and  consistency  with  ADB's  policy  on  Involuntary 
Resettlement (1995), and Policy on Indigenous People (1998), and, if gaps are 
found, recommend measures to bridge them, and assist MOWP and NTDC to 
designing the Project so as to minimize the resettlement effects; 
(ii)  in accordance with all relevant policies, handbooks, and guidelines of ADB and in 
particular  with  ADB’s  policy  on  Involuntary  Resettlement  (1995),  and  any 
applicable procedures or guidelines required by the Government, prepare and 
submit  the  draft  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  plan  and  a  resettlement 
framework to ADB for comments and approval, which should subsequently be 
incorporated  in  final  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  plan  agreed  with  the 
authorities; 
(iii)  identify and prepare socioeconomic profiles of the Project-affected communities 
in the project areas in terms of household sizes, demographic trends, income 
sources  and  levels,  occupations,  socioeconomic  conditions,  social  service 
infrastructure,  and  social  organizations,  in  accordance  with  relevant  ADB 
guidelines and publications and the requirements of Pakistan, include gender 
and local ethnic minority profiles, assess the need for an indigenous peoples 
development plan (IPDP) and an indigenous peoples development framework 
(IPDF), and conduct further surveys as necessary; 
(iv)  undertake  a  full  census  and  inventory  of  lost  assets  (loss  of  homes  and 
agricultural  and  other  lands,  or  loss  of  access  to  current  income-generating 
activities, including impacts caused by permanent or temporary acquisition) of 
affected people and a baseline socioeconomic survey of the affected population, 
determine the scope and magnitude of likely resettlement effects, and list likely 
losses of households, agricultural lands, business and income opportunities, as 
well  as  affected  communal  assets  and  public  buildings,  and  identify  and 
enumerate people likely to be affected, including impacts on the poor, indigenous 
people, ethnic minorities, and other vulnerable groups, including women, through 
a survey or census and asset inventory that identifies all types of losses; 
(v)  in consultation with MOWP and NTDC, develop an entitlement matrix, on the basis 
of the socioeconomic survey, that will determine the amount of compensation for a 
set of identified losses to ensure that any affected households will not be any 
worse  off  with  the  project  than  without  the  project  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Operations Manual F2 on Involuntary Resettlement (2003), Handbook on Poverty

12 Appendix 3 
and Social Analysis (2002); Handbook on Resettlement: A Guide to Good Practice 
(1998) and policy on Involuntary Resettlement (1995). Particular attention shall be 
given to indigenous peoples, as defined by ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples 
(1998), and other vulnerable groups, including poor households and women; 
(vi)  since  the  Project  is  likely  to  involve  significant  resettlement,  prepare  a 
resettlement  plan  with  full  stakeholder  participation,  including  participation  of 
MOWP and NTDC, that should be appropriate for the Pakistan context and still 
meet ADB policy requirements, carry out consultations with affected persons and 
community-based organizations to ensure that all affected persons have been fully 
informed of entitlements through the consultative processes initiated by MOWP 
and  NTDC,  ensure  that  communities  and  displaced  persons  understand  the 
project, its impacts and the responsibilities of parties concerned; 
(vii)  analyze and confirm the following aspects (at national and local levels) that will 
apply  to  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  in  the  Project  area:  (a)  laws  and 
regulations,  including  local  practices,  (b)  budgetary  processes  (tentative 
agreement from concerned authorities on provision of outlays necessary for land 
acquisition and resettlement), and (c) relevant administrative arrangements and 
requirements; 
(viii)  identify an independent monitoring and evaluation mechanism (to be incorporated 
in  the  project  structure)  to  assist  MOWP  and  NTDC  to  prepare  a  public 
consultation  and  disclosure  plan  to  ensure  full  stakeholder  consultation  and 
disclosure  of  the  resettlement  plan  and  any  relevant  information  to  affected 
persons during resettlement planning and implementation; and 
(ix)  on  the  basis  of  the  socioeconomic  survey,  identify  impacts  on  tribal  groups, 
determine the need for an indigenous peoples development plan, and incorporate 
provisions in the resettlement plan that are appropriate to the welfare of such 
indigenous  groups  and  consistent  with  ADB’s  policies  and  procedures  on 
indigenous peoples. 
 
F.  Reporting and Workshop Requirements 
8.  The consultants will prepare inception, interim, draft final, and final reports. Meetings 
involving MOWP, NTDC, ADB, and the consultants will be held after the submission of the 
inception, interim, and draft final reports. Other stakeholders will be invited to attend as needed. 
The consultants will prepare status reports for the specific scope of work, highlighting issues 
that could become critical for the timely completion of the TA and that require attention from 
MOWP, NTDC and/or ADB. The consultants will arrange for other workshops and on-the-job 
training for NTDC staff as required. It is expected that detailed reports and position papers will 
be required for each area of the PPTA, and these reports will form part of the interim and draft 
final reports, but should be distributed to all concerned immediately they have been completed.

INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS  
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
       
Is the sector identified as a national    Yes  Is the sector identified as a national   Yes

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan: 
 
The Government is committed in reducing poverty through economic development. Infrastructure development has 
been assessed as one of the primary needs that need to be addressed if the Government is to tackle poverty by 
enhancing economic growth. The power sector, in particular, will need considerable investment if it is to meet growth 
requirements. Electrification is an important part of achieving other development goals and therefore constitutes a 
national goal. 
 
Despite electrification and electricity consumption not really being considered as outcomes, the transmission subsector 
is considered to be fundamental for poverty reduction and economic growth as an input. Consumption patterns are also 
skewed in terms of nonpoor and poor consumers, as electricity consumption by the poor tends to be determined by 
affordability of appliances. Despite these patterns, the high connection ratios across most provinces suggest that 
capital investments in the power sector to meet future demand of existing and new consumers can be regarded as 
including the poor, both directly as consumers and indirectly through the contribution they make to enabling off-farm 
employment opportunities in the private sector and to economic growth.  
 
Poor quality and unreliable supply of power tend to disproportionately burden the poor because they are less able to 
resort to alternative sources of power. They also have fewer income sources so the loss of one may more impacts on 
poor than on nonpoor households. A reliable supply of power helps to attract commercial and industrial activities, which 
in turn may enable the poor to diversify income sources by offering more employment opportunities. The ability of 
provincial governments to fulfill economic development plans to support social development and off-farm job creation 
depends on the availability of sufficient power.  
 
In addition, a more reliable and secure supply of energy can drastically improve the quality of sanitation, healthcare and 
other social services, particularly education. 
 
Finally, a more reliable power supply can sharply increase the household living standards, by, among others, providing 
new opportunities to generate income. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
Pakistan has a complex social structure. To better understand the Project’s impact on poverty and its diverse social 
dimensions, the TA will need to use local consultants to prepare a social impact assessment and a poverty impact 
assessment, paying special attention to gender.  
 
A socioeconomic survey will be carried out and will include analysis of resettlement and indigenous peoples, although, 
at present, no indigenous peoples are thought to be affected by the Project. A poverty impact assessment will be 
undertaken separately. Form the results of these analyses, the consultants will prepare a full resettlement plan, 
incorporating mitigation measures and their costs into the project’s cost estimates. The poverty impact assessment will 
include a poverty profile, an assessment of the direct and indirect impacts on the poor, and detailed information on 
beneficiaries, particularly the poorest and the most vulnerable (paying greater attention to women).  
 
Finally, willingness to pay, tariff and affordability analyses will also be carried out to improve understanding of the 
general impacts (positive and negative) on the poor and other vulnerable groups.
